Is Halo Infinite the return of a legend or an attempt to revive the franchise?  
An overview of an ordinary player who grew up on Halo, but is not afraid to tell the truth.

---

When Microsoft announced Halo Infinite in 2020, fans around the world held their breath. After all, it wasn't just a new game ‚Äî it was a promise to bring back the "Golden Age" of first-person shooters, an era when Halo 2 and Halo 3 forced schoolchildren to hide their Xbox under their desks in order to have time to play before the bell rang. However, what we got in the end is not just a game. This is a story about high ambitions, technical failures and an unexpected rescue.

---

üåå Plot and atmosphere: "The Master Chief is against everything"

Halo Infinite unfolds events immediately after the events of *Halo 5: Guardians*. Master Chief, one of the most iconic characters in the history of video games, finds himself alone on the destroyed Zeta Halo ring structure, with almost no memory and a broken suit. His ally is AI **The Weapon**, a conscious copy of Cortana, who is trying to figure out why she exists.

The plot doesn't break your brain, but it's atmospheric, emotional, and sometimes even philosophical. Especially if you've been following the saga from the beginning. There is no overload of dialogues or characters here ‚Äî everything is focused on the Chief, his inner struggle and reconnecting with humanity. And yes, the finale leaves a light aftertaste... and a burning desire to see the sequel.

---

Gameplay: freedom, but with caveats

The company is, perhaps, the main trump card of Halo Infinite. Unlike its linear predecessors, here you will find an open world on a huge ring structure. You can explore locations, clear out the bases of banshee bandits, find secrets, upgrade the Chief's abilities - all this in a free manner.

The gameplay is back to basics: ** No exoskeletons**, **No teleporters** ‚Äî just stormtroopers, shields, grenades and your mind. The Return of the Grappling Hook (Grappleshot)** it has become a game changer: with its help, you can both accelerate in battle and perform spectacular jumping tricks. You can feel the weight of the Chief's body ‚Äî he's not a superhero, he's a soldier, and this has its own aesthetic.

However, **artificial intelligence** is a sore spot. Enemies often behave strangely, especially in difficult levels. It happens that the elites just stand and wait for their death, instead of attacking. It spoils the impression, especially when you want to feel challenged.

---

, Graphics and technical side

At the time of release (December 2021), Halo Infinite looked like... ** modestly **. Many fans criticized her for her "plastic" graphics and empty landscapes. But Microsoft and studio 343 Industries** did something that developers rarely do ‚Äî they  listened to the community.

Over the past two years, the game has received ** many updates**: improved terrain texture, added dynamic lighting and weather, redesigned animations. Today, Halo Infinite looks the way it should have looked when it was released ‚Äî beautiful, large-scale, epic.

---

üïπÔ∏è Multiplayer: Chaos, but fun

Multiplayer in Halo Infinite is free ‚Äî and this is a bold step. It brings back the classic gameplay: Slayer, Capture the Flag, Big Team Battle** on huge maps with tanks and helicopters. All this works on an updated version of the Slipspace Engine, created specifically for this game.

Problems? Yes, they were. At the start ‚Äî inconvenient menu,  lack of rating modes,  problems with weapon balance. But gradually 343 Industries fixed everything. Today, multiplayer is a **live community** where beginners can practice and veterans can hone their skills.

---

Historical context: from Bungie to 343 Industries

Halo was born within the walls of Bungie, a studio that gave us not only a cult shooter, but also a cultural phenomenon. The first game was released in 2001 exclusively on Xbox and became a "system game" ‚Äî without it, the console simply did not make sense.

But in 2007, Bungie left Microsoft, leaving the franchise in the hands of an internal studio, 343 Industries, named after one of the AI characters in the Halo universe. At first, fans were skeptical about the change of creators, but Halo 4 (2012) and Halo 5 (2015) Proved that the spirit of the series is alive.

Halo Infinite was conceived as a **relaunch**, but with respect for the legacy. And although its development was accompanied by layoffs, leaks and internal conflicts, the game eventually became what many were waiting for: ** a love letter to fans from themselves**.

---

Conclusion: is it worth playing?

yes. Necessarily.  
Halo Infinite is not perfect, but it is ** honest**. It shows that even in the era of battle royales and loot boxes, it is possible to make a shooter in which the main values are freedom, tactics and a sense of adventure.

If you:
- we grew up on Halo 2 over a LAN network,
- Do you want to experience nostalgia with a modern look,
- just looking for a high-quality shooter with a soul,

‚Äî then **Halo Infinite** is your choice.

And if you don't believe me, just download the multiplayer for free and see for yourself: The chief is still in business**.

[h1]Review After 100% Completion[/h1]

[h2]Recommendation: Recommended[/h2]

[h3]What I Liked (Pros):[/h3]
+ Sandbox gameplay is peak Halo. Grappling around Zeta Halo, launching fusion coils, hijacking vehicles mid-air, it‚Äôs the most fun I‚Äôve had in a Halo game. The freedom and creativity in combat are unmatched.
+ Best-feeling Halo in the series. Movement is fluid, responsive, and empowering. The grapple hook alone changes everything, traversal, combat, exploration, it‚Äôs a game-changer.
+ Open world exploration feels right. Landing on the ring and being free to roam, uncover secrets, and tackle objectives in any order captures the spirit of what Halo always hinted at.
+ The Banished and the Endless are incredible factions. The Banished bring raw brutality, while the Endless introduce terrifying lore implications. [spoiler] The idea that they‚Äôre immune to the rings, more dangerous than the Flood, [/spoiler] is wild.
+ Legendary ending teases something huge. [spoiler] Atriox being revealed alive after seemingly dying off-screen is a massive twist. Replacing him with Escharum felt like a downgrade at first, but knowing he‚Äôs still out there sets the stage for something epic.[/spoiler]
+ Multiplayer is finally in top form. With Forge, custom games, new modes, and balance updates, it‚Äôs the best Halo multiplayer has been in years.
+ Co-op campaign is a blast. Playing through the story with a friend, unlocking co-op achievements, and coordinating attacks was super fun.
+ LASO is actually fun. Unlike previous Halo LASO runs, this one lets you carry the tank gun the entire time, and grappling around speedrunning it with a friend was an absolute blast.
+ Cortana‚Äôs arc is surprisingly powerful. Her off-screen death early on felt like a letdown, but the full picture reveals a tragic redemption. [spoiler] From coldly executing Spartans to sacrificing herself to destroy the ring mid-activation, her story ends on a high note.[/spoiler]
+ The Weapon (Joy) is a standout. Her dynamic with Chief, especially the moment she learns [spoiler] he tried to delete her, is raw and emotional. The awkward tension, the trust rebuild, and her growth are handled beautifully.[/spoiler]
+ The Pilot adds heart. His fear, vulnerability, and connection to Chief humanize the story. Seeing Chief care about marine losses and comfort the pilot, all while never removing his helmet, is masterful. If only the TV show understood that. No one needed to see Chief‚Äôs cheeks.
+ Boss fights are a major step up. Halo Infinite finally delivers memorable boss encounters. Standouts include: Escharum, The Harbinger & Jega 'Rdomnai.

[h3]What I Didn‚Äôt Like (Cons):[/h3]
- No campaign DLC. The Legendary ending begged for continuation, and the Endless deserved more screen time. It‚Äôs a huge missed opportunity.
- Lack of biome variety. The campaign sticks to one terrain type, forested mountains. No deserts, snowfields, swamps, or alien zones. It makes the ring feel smaller than it should.
- [spoiler] No Flood appearance. Even a late-game tease would‚Äôve been enough. Their absence feels like a gap in the Halo DNA, though shoehorning them in might‚Äôve felt forced.[/spoiler]
- Staggered launch hurt momentum. Releasing campaign and multiplayer separately fractured the experience. If it had all dropped together, fully featured, it would‚Äôve landed way harder.

[h3]Wishlist ‚Äì Things I‚Äôd Love to See Added:[/h3]
[list]
[*] Campaign DLC ‚Äì Expand the story, explore the Endless, and give us new biomes and missions.
[*] Biome Diversity ‚Äì Snow, sand, alien structures, anything to break up the visual monotony. 
[*] Flood Encounter ‚Äì Even a short arc or side mission would‚Äôve added tension and nostalgia. 
[*] Unified Launch Model ‚Äì Future Halo entries should release campaign and multiplayer together, fully featured. 
[*] Incentives to Replay Campaign ‚Äì More unlocks, secrets, or progression tied to campaign completion would help.
[/list]

[h3]Achievements:[/h3]
Most achievements in Halo Infinite are straightforward and can be earned through exploration, combat creativity, and completing campaign objectives. The good news is that nearly all missions are replayable, so there‚Äôs very little risk of permanently missing anything, a huge plus for completionists.

There are a few that require extra attention:
[list]
[*] Headmaster ‚Äì Complete all missions on Legendary with all Skulls active (LASO). It‚Äôs tough, but this version is actually fun thanks to the tank gun. Grappling around the map and speedrunning it with a friend made it one of the most enjoyable LASO runs in the series.
[*] Wolves at the Doors - In co-op, lower all three gates within 15 seconds of each other at Riven Gate, hard with 2 or less players.
[*] Controlled Demolition - In co-op, destroy four Fuel Silos within five seconds at either Ransom Keep or the Forge of Teash.
[/list]
The only real grind in the campaign comes from collecting all the upgrades and collectibles. You‚Äôll need a minimum of two saves: one for tracking and collecting everything, and another dedicated to speedrunning missions and completing LASO. Overall, it‚Äôs a fair achievement list, just keep an eye on your progress and clean up as you go.

[h3]Memorable Quotes:[/h3]
[list]
[*] "The ring is not your salvation. It is your prison." 
[*] "We are the harbingers of your end." 
[*] "You have been freed. But you are not free." 
[*] ‚ÄúThe missions change. They always do.‚Äù 
[*] ‚ÄúWe all fail. We all make mistakes. It‚Äôs what makes us human.‚Äù
[/list]

[h3]Final Thoughts:[/h3]
Halo Infinite gets so much right. The sandbox is brilliant, the movement feels nice, and the factions are some of the best in the franchise. Grappling through Zeta Halo, launching into fights, and piecing together the mystery of the Endless feels like classic Halo with a modern twist.

But it also feels like a game that missed its moment. If it had launched with everything it has now, co-op, Forge, polished multiplayer, and dropped campaign and multiplayer together, it could‚Äôve been a cultural reset for Halo. Instead, the staggered release and free-to-play multiplayer split the player base. It brought more cheaters, fewer incentives to stick around, and left a lot of players skipping the campaign entirely,  which is a shame, because it‚Äôs genuinely great.

A lot of people probably bounced off early when they found out Atriox and Cortana were killed off-screen. [spoiler] It felt like a massive L at first. But the payoff later, Atriox being alive, Cortana‚Äôs redemption, and Chief‚Äôs emotional arc, really lands. [/spoiler] The way they handled Chief‚Äôs grief, his bond with the pilot, and his evolving relationship with The Weapon (Joy) was some of the best character work the series has ever done.

And the voice acting? Absolutely top-tier. Jen Taylor voiced Halsey, Cortana, and The Weapon (Joy), and you can clearly tell them apart. Her performance, alongside Steve Downes as Chief, carries the emotional weight of the entire story. If either of them ever gets replaced, the soul of this franchise goes with them.

And on the multiplayer side, unlocking the samurai armour and earning the Hayabusa armour again, just like I did back in Halo 3, was a nostalgic high. It brought back that same sense of pride and grind, and it was awesome to see it return in Infinite.

Still, what‚Äôs here is excellent. It‚Äôs the most fun I‚Äôve had in a Halo game since Reach. And if they ever drop that campaign expansion? I‚Äôll be first in line.

Remember when 343 said they had a 10-year plan for this game? That fell apart almost immediately. At launch, Infinite felt fresh fun gameplay, fluid movement, and a lot of promise. But after 2,000 hours, you start to see all the cracks.

Ever since the so-called ‚Äúnetwork update‚Äù about a year ago, the experience for me as a PC player has been steadily going downhill. Anything above 80 ping and the game becomes borderline unplayable constant blanks, heavy aim, broken hit registration, grenades disappearing midair, and rockets that simply don‚Äôt fire or explode. The gun-play feels great mechanically, but the networking and desync completely ruin it.

343 has had control of the Halo franchise for over a decade now, and after three mainline games, it still feels like they‚Äôve learned nothing. ‚ÄúOne step forward, three steps back‚Äù should honestly be their company slogan at this point. Infinite nails the fundamentals the art direction feels closer to Bungie‚Äôs golden era, your Spartan feels agile and grounded, and movement is crisp like Halo 2 and Halo 3 not the hyper-speed, twitchy mess of Halo 4 and 5. The insider flight tests were amazing, the community feedback was overwhelmingly positive, and everyone was saying, ‚ÄúHalo is back.‚Äù Then the game actually launched‚Ä¶ and it was the exact opposite of what we were promised.
The live service model is a desperate cash grab. Six years of development, over a hundred developers, and half a billion dollars yet Halo Infinite still has less content than most $40 indie shooters. They marketed it as ‚Äúfree to play,‚Äù but still charged $60 for the campaign which itself launched incomplete, lacking mission replay, co-op, or proper progression for months.

They promised ‚ÄúHalo Reach-level customization‚Äù and delivered a system where 85% of all cosmetics are locked behind paywalls or FOMO-limited event passes. You either grind through uninspired event challenges or pay up. And even then, the shop prices are ridiculous.

The population drop tells the story: from millions at launch to under 7k daily players. For a franchise as legendary as Halo, that‚Äôs depressing. It‚Äôs a shell of what it used to be.

I was excited for Halo Infinite from the start, between the flights and the multiplayer previews, I was ready to hop in to a new era of Halo. I lived through the content droughts and the mixed messaging from the developer. I stuck with this game for the past 4 years as my main. When I sat down to play, it was Halo Infinite.

I mainly play ranked arena, so my review is mainly coming from that of a competitive perspective. With the latest update, 343i/Halo Studios have made the game unplayable. I know there's been a lot of talk about SBMM over the past few years, but somehow Halo Infinite's is by far the most aggressive implementation I've ever seen. The game actively does not want you to progress in the ranks. Once the game has you locked into the rank that it thinks you are supposed to be at, the SBMM will do everything in it's power to make sure that you stay stuck at that rank for good. I have gone from winning a game or two, to losing upwards of ten in a row before the game will "bless" me with a blood and sweat induced victory that could be attributed more to luck than actual skill. The winning streaks are few and far between, and the losing streaks are abundant. Halo Infinite is one of the least rewarding games I have ever played.

This next section falls into the "I can't prove it, but I know it's true, trust be bro" category. 
Halo Infinite actively manipulates the way the game functions in order to suppress ranks. If the game detects that you are getting too high in rank, it actively pairs you up with your weaker game modes on your weaker maps with teammates who are also playing their weaker game modes and maps, against teams of players on their strongest maps and game types with a much higher hidden MMR ranking. The game continuously does this until you are back at the rank you are "supposed" to be at. The game will also do things like manipulate hit boxes, manipulate aim assist, manipulate grenade trajectory and explosion times, manipulate explosion radius, manipulate melee lunge range all in the name of keeping you at a competitive disadvantage. All of this influenced by a hidden rank that you can't see, and was set for you after the game first came out and hasn't been reset. This makes the game utterly un-fun to play.

All of this sucks, because at it's core, Halo Infinite is the most mechanically and fundamentally sound games that 343i/Halo Studios has ever released. When everything is functioning, and players are on an equal playing field, the game is fun as heck to play, but at this point, I can't recommend any attempt to get into it, or for anyone to continue playing it.

This game was supposed to be the start of a ten year live service cycle for Halo. Now, 4 years later, Halo Studios has killed it. For what, you may ask? A Halo: Combat Evolved remake that nobody asked for. I guess Halo Infinite was the last piece of the franchise's rotting corpse that could be paraded around for all to see. It would have been much better for them to bring Halo MCC to Playstation, rather than remaking a 25 year old game with new "modern mechanics" that drastically alters how the game functions.

My rating, 2 out of 5. It sucks what this whole thing turned into, and I'm not excited for Halo's future.
